title: 15-150: Principles of Functional Programming
description: This looks like an interesting course to have a look at. I quickly watched the first lecture. Might be worth looking at some of the others

title: Nice bike | Seth's Blog
description: Seth hits it on the head as always - the need to be happy with the vehicle you have for the journey you're travelling. What is the journey you want to travel? Is the vehicle that you're using the right one? Is the journey the right one?

title: Ancient Tree Inventory - Woodland Trust
description: This feels like a cool project. It has maps! Mapping the oldest and most important trees in the UK. Interesting in the light of the one that got cut down in the gap.

title: GitHub - cxli233/FriendsDontLetFriends: Friends don't let friends make certain types of data visualization - What are they and why are they bad.
description: This feels like a good resource when looking at data visualisations with students - when certain data viz are the wrong choice and why

title: A Tour of the Tektronix Ceramic CRT “Catacombs”
description: Always cool to think about and see the history of tech. Before printed circuit boards there were other approaches to keep your components in line - this shows how one company did it with ceramics.

title: How to shuffle songs? - Spotify Engineering : Spotify Engineering
description:
I used to talk about randomness with my students when I taught maths and we specifically talked about how the iPod shuffle had to be de-randomised in order to make it feel more random.

Interesting that Spotify seem to be coming to the party late here - one of those situations where we don't have a lot of history, so we have to reinvent the wheel?
Interesting that this is seen as such a problem - there is so much overhead to get Node and TS to play together and good to have an attempt to codify. I think I'd like to redo this with TSX
title: A Node + TypeScript + ts-node + ESM experience that works. · GitHub

description: I know this probably got thrown up in my feed because of the whole OpenAI saga going on but it's interesting to see others learning journies. I think I'd be interested in an ML exploration but I'm not convinced that it's a high enough proirity to what I'm doing right now.
title: How I became a machine learning practitioner

description:
This is great - and love the name of the blog!

I'm currently commuting to my own office but as long as I have a choice, I don't want to share an office with anyone else. Commuting in my case is hopeful to change but necessary with family life right now.
title: Return To Office Mandates Can Take A Hike
Pretty Diff - Guide, The DOM Explained, Quick and Simple
description: This was labelled "How to Write a Parser" - that's something I'd like to dive into more. I've only scanned this quickly but it seems interesting. Filing it for future reference.
Speaking of ML and self-directed learning this could be an interesting course to dive into if that did tickle my fancy. Based in PyTorch.
title: UNIGE 14x050 – Deep Learning

description: Ah! I talked to Simon about this last night and I think I'd like to write a blog post about this - how hard (impossible?) it is for us to land in a new project and get a theory of how it all works just from the code and the docs. Super hard when you're a consultant and both you and the client want you to be able to deliver value as quickly as possible
title: Suddenly, I Understand Software

description: This is a fun list of things that I've seen come and go - some are still here!! How dare they say jQuery is old school.
title: Old School Web Techniques Best Forgotten | WDD
30 Bits of Advice for 30 Years
description: Always fun to see people try to condense their life lessons - helpful exercise for them and helpful for the reader to either agree/disagree with the points made.

I read this story before when it was first published - it was sad then and feels even more poignant now. Justlife are doing amazing stuff in Brighton - I wonder what an equivalent charity in Belfast is? Wonder if I'd have the capacity to help out?
title: The invisible city: how a homeless man built a life underground | Homelessness | The Guardian

description: There's a whole series here I'd like to work through and get good at - I think being able to help people through email is a good thing, I'm just not very good at it.
title: How to Succeed with ConvertKit (Part I)  - Stacking the Bricks
The power of defaults «  julian.digital
description: Love the website heading here but more really enjoyed this article and style of writing

title: 30 pandas Commands for Manipulating DataFrames
description: Could be a useful list when working on a Pandas course.

This seems like an interesting technique - I'd wonder about it making things read less clearly but there may be performance benefits? Although, the creation of all those intermediary arrays might also be costly?
title: Filter and map Array values with a flatMap one-liner | Stefan Judis Web Development

description:
This is interesting - engineers want three things:
- Cool stuff to work on.
- Smart people to work with.
- Some degree of repeatability in work environment.

That's an interesting list - how does that map for the independent?
title: I Think I Know Why You Can't Hire Engineers Right NowI Think I Know Why You Can’t Hire Engineers Right Now | Wherein The Chicken
unixsheikh.com
description: I like the filter between articles and tutorials - worth doing for my blog?

title: Hi, my name is Sander Heilbron
description: I quite like his socials in the footer

title: Living On 24 Hours A Day | Justin Fuller
description: This is a really good review of a book from 1908. How we can live meaningfully with the hours we have - not more productively but deeper. Taking some of that down time that we doom scroll or commute and using it to learn or explore, draw or create.
This looks like a really interesting project - I wonder if there's a JS Node equivalent - I know there is Chalk and a few others but this seems richer
title: GitHub - Textualize/rich: Rich is a Python library for rich text and beautiful formatting in the terminal.

description: This is an awesome article on Cognitive Load Theory - really well illustrated and some excellent applications to students
title: Cognitive Load Theory and its Applications for Learning - Scott H Young
Teaching how to code is broken
description: Advocates taking a large problem or game and using that as the vehicle to explore teachin

title: woob - Web Outside of Browsers
description: Interesting to think about the web outisde of a browser - we have access to all this information and the browser does lots to help us see and visualise it - but we could also interact with it in different ways. can see the need for accessibility - but also wonder what other uses we could put this structured data to?
I needed this article a while ago - and now I'm in Astro land I think I can use and implement this. A code editor component is probably in my very near future
title: Building A Web Code Editor — Smashing Magazine

description: I love these lists - awesome lists are awesome - interesting to look through and see if there's anything that catches my interest

description: This is very cool - compositie maps of maps

description: This is a good list
title: The Boring Technology Checklist

description: I quite like Tiago Forte's COPE process - and I think this list of bookmarks is part of my collect stage. I wonder if there is a need to mark some as private? I know tags help to hold them together and I can see a future where I create note pages that can pull these together. These bookmarks feel like a building block for future work and this article talks about something similar - that this collecting and sorting is a form of R&D
title: Unconscious R&D - by Gordon Brander - Subconscious

description: How long are websites designed to last for - I'm hoping this site will last a while and am keen for it to grow organically as the need arises.

description: Explore the counter-factual - write a "why shouldn't we do this?" instead of just the positive. Create a steel man argument - not a straw one!
title: Show the case against | Shubhro Saha
In Defence of the Boring Web
description: This fits in with the building sites that last for a very long time point I came across recently.

This is awesome - a really clear tutorial in a single js file using comments really effectively.

Clear that teaching doesn't need bells and whistles if it's clear. Could this be enhanced with more interactivity? Maybe but you'd also reduce the ability for others to use it
